node.title: OM – Advaitic Songs
node.content: Philosophy/Religion. Heavy ascends to a level it would have been impossible to foresee, decimated by sheer imagination and expansive quality.
node.excerpt: Advaitic Songs by OM Philosophy/Religion. Heavy ascends to a level it would have been impossible to foresee, decimated by sheer imagination and expansive quality.

node.title: L’Eclair – Polymood
node.content: “Polymood” is a further expansion on L’Eclair’s quest to channel and honor their Afro-Disco, Kosmische, and early House 70s influences. And what we end up with is a collection of timeless Swiss Groove™ music—inspired by William Onyeabor, French band AIR, Piero Picioni, Sly Stone and CAN’s ‘Future Days’—bringing euphoric dance to the human machine while it perseveres in its never-ending search for the soul.

node.title: DIIV – Deceiver
node.content: Rebirth takes place when everything falls apart. DIIV—Zachary Cole Smith [lead vocals, guitar], Andrew Bailey [guitar], Colin Caulfield [vocals, bass], and Ben Newman [drums]—craft the soundtrack to personal resurrection under the heavy weight of metallic catharsis upheld by robust guitars and vocal tension that almost snaps, but never quite.
node.excerpt: Deceiver by DIIV Rebirth takes place when everything falls apart. DIIV—Zachary Cole Smith [lead vocals, guitar], Andrew Bailey [guitar], Colin Caulfield [vocals, bass], and Ben Newman [drums]—craft the soundtrack to personal resurrection under the heavy weight of metallic catharsis upheld by robust guitars and vocal tension that almost snaps, but never quite.

node.title: Albums of the decade 2010 -2019
node.content:
Another decade has passed and the future has officially arrived – 2020 occurs one year later than the period of original Blade Runner’s world. In terms of music, 2010-2019 was one of the best decades. In terms of private life, it was one of the most beautiful and the hardest periods in which I experienced the greatest love and got through the greatest of pains.

The decade began in a slightly sad and melancholic tone. I listened to Massive Attack’s Heligoland during the winter 2010 while receiving an antibiotic therapy – and this was the overall feel of that year: cold, sad and lonely. The next two years were alright, but nothing seemed to be as it should. As I remember, there was that winter feel all over. I guess listening to Kate Bush’s 50 Words For Snow helped maintain that feeling.

The Black Keys where a leftover from a previous life, while Tame Impala lead me into modern psychedelic rock. I listened to Melody’s Echo Chamber while learning French and Kurt Vile’s Walking On A Pretty Daze took me to sunny places.

I met the love of my life on Zdravo Mladi Festival. We talked about The Soft Moon’s performance at the festival and stayed together for the whole night (and we’ve been together ever since). In 2015, he played me Birds of passage and her nocturnal music took the form of the pain that I carried inside me. In 2016, we saw Föllakzoid and Moon Duo playing at the same festival. The following year, there was Slowdive. In the recent years, the festival’s programme began to cater the tastes in music embraced by younger generations, so we lost interest.

2017 was definitely the year of King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard and the sweet discovery of Australia’s music scene. 2018 was the year of psychedelic (guitar) music coming from all corners of the world: Wooden Shjips, The Babe Rainbow, Kikagaku Mojo, Minami Deutsch. The re-listening to Dead can Dance’s catalog represented a rediscovery of a new, long forgotten world.

2019 was an year of calmness and introspection, setting life priorities straight and greater restriction of the things that I let occupy my time and mental space. Tranquility and harmony, backed up by ambient music that was played by, well, you know who. The event of the year was the Dead can Dance’s concert in Budapest. Last minute tickets secured us places in the last row of a gargantuan sports arena. Yet, all of that was insignificant in comparison to the beauty of the sonic spectacle provided by Lisa and Brendan who marked their thirty-ninth anniversary of the band’s existence.

This is the list of the most listened to records of the last decade:

2010

  • Massive Attack – Heligoland (2010)
  • The National – High Violet (2010)
  • Grinderman – Grinderman 2 (2010)

2011

  • PJ Harvey – Let England Shake (2011)
  • Kate Bush – 50 Words for Snow (2011)
  • Bill Callahan – Apocalypse (2011)
  • Radiohead – The King of Limbs (2011)
  • Little Dragon – Ritual Union (2011)

2012

  • The Black Keys – Brothers (2010)
  • The Black Keys – El Camino (2011)
  • Tindersticks – The Something Rain (2012)
  • Wild Nothing – Nocturne (2012)
  • Cat Power – Sun (2012)
  • Bat For Lashes – The Haunted Man (2012)

2013

  • Tame Impala – Innerspeaker (2010)
  • Tame Impala – Lonerism (2012)
  • Melody’s Echo Chamber – Melody’s Echo Chamber (2012)
  • Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds – Push the sky away (2013)
  • Daughter – If you leave (2013)
  • Rhye – Woman (2013)

2014

  • The Soft Moon – The Soft Moon (2010)
  • Darkside (Nicolas Jaar) – Psychic (2013)
  • Kurt Vile – Walking on a pretty daze (2013)

2015

  • Grouper – AIA: Alien Observer (2011)
  • Dawn of Midi – Dysomnia (2013)
  • Birds of Passage – This Kindly Slumber (2014)
  • Tame Impala – Currents (2015)
  • A Place to Bury Strangers – Transfixiation (2015)

2016

  • Moon Duo – Circles (2012)
  • Föllakzoid – II (2013)
  • Cosmonauts – Persona Non Grata (2013)
  • Kreidler – ABC (2014)
  • Holy Wave – Relax (2014)
  • Föllakzoid – III (2015)
  • New Candys – New Candys As Medicine (2015)
  • Cosmonauts – A-OK (2016)

2017

  • OM – Advaitic Songs (2012)
  • Cave – Threace (2013)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Quarters (2015)
  • SUUNS – Hold/Still (2016)
  • K-X-P – III, Pt.1 (2016)
  • Moon Duo – Occult Architecture (2017)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Flying Microtonal Banana (2017), Polygonwannaland (2017), Sketches of Brunswick East (2017)
  • Slowdive – Slowdive (2017)

2018

  • Wooden Shjips – Back to Land (2013)
  • Minami Deutsch – Minami Deutsch (2014)
  • The Babe Rainbow – The Babe Rainbow (2015)
  • Naxatras – Naxatras (2015)
  • Unknown Mortal Orchestra – Multi-love (2015)
  • Kikagaku Moyo – House in the Tall Grass (2016)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Gumboot Soup (2017)
  • Biblical – The City That Always Sleeps (2017)
  • Dead Can Dance – Dionysus (2018)
  • Wooden Shjips – V (2018)
  • The Babe Rainbow – Double Rainbow (2018)
  • Kikagaku Moyo – Masana Temples (2018)
  • Minami Deutsch – With Dim Light (2018)
  • Dungen/Woods – Myths 003 (2018)
  • Triptides – Visitors (2018)
  • Hookworms – Microshift (2018)
  • Mild Orange – Foreplay (2018)

2019

  • Gaussian Curve – Impossible Island (2015)
  • Juana Molina – Halo (2017)
  • Skinshape – Filoxiny (2018)
  • Beak> – >>> (2018)
  • Claypool Lennon Delirium – South of Reality (2019)
  • Moon Duo – Stars are the Light (2019)
  • DIIV – Deceiver (2019)

In terms of music, 2010-2019 was one of the best decades. In terms of private life, it was one of the most beautiful and the hardest periods in which I experienced the greatest love and got through the greatest of pains….

node.title: Past, Present and Yet To Come: The music of 2018
node.content:
It is amazing how easily I got used to the new year and 2018 already seams so far away. Throughout December I was thinking back to the year that passed by, but I got the festive blues and couldn’t find the strength to summarize it. On Christmas Eve I gathered my thoughts and, just like in the Christmas Carol, I let the Ghosts of the Past, the Present and the Yet To Come to remind me on what was before, how is it now and what the future might be.

Past

I spent large portion of 2018 with the music of Kate Bush. I cannot even explain myself what kind of a force is it that drags me towards her, but her music simply enchants me. Hearing her saying „Take my shoes off/ and throw them in the lake“, I literally feel the urge to throw my shoes and simply start walking wherever my feet may take me. I mostly listened to The Sensual World, Hounds of Love and Aerial.

Smashing Pumpkins were a big deal for me back in the ‘90s, spending hours and hours listening to Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness, Siamese Dream and Pisces Iscariot. Yet, their debut album Gish remained quite unfamiliar, so this year I went back to correct that.

Gish has the unfortunate destiny to be constantly compared, and thus overshadowed, by Nirvana’s Nevermind, both produced by Butch Vig (Garbage) and released the same year of 1991. Unlike Nirvana, Smashing Pumpkins did not gain much of a fame and fortune at that time, but merely appeared on the scene and announced their presence. However, the following years they took over the alternative rock music scene and marked the music of the ‘90s. This year The Smashing Pumpkins made a come-back with a new album and a tour named “Shiny And Oh So Bright” which I gladly awaited. But, I regret to state that these Smashing Pumpkins are some faded away version of that once cool band from the ‘90s. They had it, they lost it.

This year marks 20 years from the releasing of Air’s debut album Moon Safari. All these years I’ve never stopped listening to this album and I’ve never ever got bored of it. Being unpretentious and modest, it is a unique masterpiece combining electronic music, jazz, synth-pop, space-rock and trip-hop with a French twist.

Reading the memoir “Drugs are nice” by Lisa Crystal Carver (Lisa Suckdog), a former partner of Bill Callahan, led me to re-listen his 2011 album Apocalypse. I love it how the sound on this album is so crisp and clear that I have the feeling I can almost touch it.

From the memoir one could get the picture for the most obscure underground scene of the ‘80s and early ‘90s, various experimental and noise rock musicians, performance artists and complete lunatics like GG Allin, which were Lisa’s friends. I couldn’t understand how could the eccentric Lisa and the quiet Bill ever get along. She wanted to become famous, and Bill didn’t have much of ambitions. From today’s perspective, they both achieved the totally opposite.

Present

During January we had the time to listen to King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard’s Gumboot Soup which came out at the very end of 2017. The alternative Australian scene was a sweet discovery, but the music coming from Japan was even more exotic. The psychedelic and kraut rock music of Japanese bands Kikagaku Moyo and Minami Deutch and their 2018 albums Masana Temples and With Dim Light respectively were one of the most listened throughout 2018.

The summer was marked by psychedelic rock listening to Wooden Shjips, Double Rainbow and Triptides. We saw Wooden Shjips at Zdravo Mladi Festival in September and the good old San-Fran hippies took us on a ride to the psychedelic landscapes of their music. Their melodies are crazy enough to be fun, but carefully dosed not to be heavy to digest.

At the beginning of December Dead Can Dance released their latest album Dionysus, which consists of seven songs divided in two parts named Act I and Act II and it covers different aspects of the myth of the ancient god Dionysus. The music on the album has this specific Balkan melody while the band was using instruments from all over the world.

There is something primordial in the music of Dead Can Dance which I recognize as something that belongs to me, like some long forgotten part of myself. I immediately fell in love with this album.

Yet To Come

I wrongfully ignored the Ghost of the Yet To Come and didn’t assume that he could bring me another loss of a loved one at the very beginning of the year. For better or worse, once faced with a great loss in life, one learns how to deal with future pains of such scale. It doesn’t get easier, but you nevertheless learn.

I want to believe in the philosophy of the Tralfamadorians from Kurt Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-Five who perceive time as a whole and the destiny of every human as an eternal present. According to them, when someone dies, it just seems so, because one is still alive in the past.

I like that idea. It gives me comfort and soothes me.
node.excerpt: It is amazing how easily I got used to the new year and 2018 already seams so far away. Throughout December I was thinking back to the year that passed by, but I got the festive blues and couldn’t find the strength to summarize it. On Christmas Eve I gathered my thoughts and, just like…

node.title: Mandy: Revenge saga in praise of love
node.content:
The horror genre represents more than just a shocking and mindless entertainment involving killers, monsters and screaming in panic. The cinematographic terror that horror offers comes in many sub-genre forms that are quite successful in stimulating the hidden fears and phobias of the audience. In his recent horror flick Mandy (2018), the Canadian director of Greek origin, Panos Cosmatos, managed to create a visually impressive and thematically rich work of art that is able to penetrate the boundaries set by genre.

Mandy is a two part film, the first one being slow, calm, psychedelic and esoteric, while the other part is fast, ruthless, bloody and filled with action, and in some instances rather comical. In terms of its visual aesthetics, Mandy emanates with an incredible color range. The colors give an impression the audience is faced with a surreal environment, a dream, a fantasy parade or a psychedelic trip.

The first part of the film depicts Mandy (Andrea Riseborough) and Red (Nicolas Cage), a modest pair living modest lives doing modest jobs. Red is a lumberjack, while Mandy works at small convenience store. They spend their time in conversation about ordinary and unusual things, about their favorite planets and their growing pains. The love, harmony and understating between them reveals that their modest way of life is sufficient for happiness. Their house is in the middle of the woods and has huge glass windows that distort the light and create an ambiance of a perfectly isolated bubble.

Still, Mandy is not an ordinary girl. Her long black hair, big eyes and black clothes reveal the witch. She paints terrific paintings, reads occult literature and is an astrology enthusiast. Mandy is magical and mysterious, walks with the shoulders straight, talks calmly and self-confidently.

In contrast, there is Jeremiah (Linus Roache), a total opposite of Mandy. He is a failed folk singer/songwriter and a leader of a small cult. This narcissist is surrounded by his docile followers, a small band of petty losers. Jeremiah persuades himself and the others that he is not an ordinary man, that god granted him special powers and the right to do and posses whatever he wants. He demonstrates supremacy and divinity, but the low self opinion eats him from the inside. His character is a reminiscent of a manipulative leader of a religious or satanist cult, a hippy movement, a party leader, a group of hooligans or a criminal organization. And, as in the case of many of such individuals, Jeremiah’s hands are not drenched in blood, but the ruthless acts of evil are committed by his followers.

While walking in the woods all by herself, Mandy meets Jeremiah and, even though the encounter lasts only for a moment, he becomes obsessed with her and the idea that he must posses her. Using the help of a group of monstrous creatures, his cult manages to imprison and later torture Mandy and Red. In a hell infused by psychedelics, Jeremiah is unable to mindfuck Mandy in submission. Verbally, she is able to hit him right in the soft spot – his shaky ego.

The turn of the events goes further down the spiral and this is the moment when the first part of the film ends. The scene in which Red, recently traumatized by the demonic cult, sits on the toilet sit and starts drinking alcohol uncontrollably, leads us into the second part of the movie that represents a revenge saga, a festival of brutality and a proper meat grinder. The scene is both sad and funny at the same time. It is easy to notice the juxtaposition between, on one hand Red’s funny looks – a bloody head and dressed only in his undies and silly t-shirt, and on the other – the volcano of emotions that erupt out of him.

In a great extent, the atmospheric music of the Icelandic author Jóhann Jóhannsson complements to the film’s surreal ambience. Partially programmed and partially live, Jóhannsson’s music contributes to the completion of the dark, violent and full-on insane atmosphere.

Mandy represents an aesthetic perfection and much more than a plain one-dimensional horror film. Perhaps it was Comatos’ intention to target the true fans of horror cinema, but I saw the movie from a different angle. Despite the terror and bloodbath, for me, Mandy is a story that praises love. I guess I’m a hopeless romantic.

“You made this song? And it’s about you?!”

The cinematographic terror that horror offers comes in many sub-genre forms that are quite successful in stimulating the hidden fears and phobias of the audience. In his recent horror flick Mandy (2018), the Canadian director of…

node.title: A psychedelic summer triptych
node.content:
As far as I could remember, in the current year we are experiencing one of the most untypical summers. Cloudy days and temperatures below 40 degrees Celsius. I like this kind of weather since I am not a huge fan of the continental summers and extremely high temperatures (but then again, who is?). The summer heat makes me numb. It blurs my mind and it takes away the ability to think rationally. Each time the sun obliterates we me with radiation, I think of Meursault and his silly justification that he shoot the Arab only due to the sun blinding him.

However, even though I can’t take the heat, I can’t help liking the summer and all that it symbolizes: vitality, youth, energy, romance, passion. I like the summer relaxation and carelessness. The unique feeling that you are on your summer break, even though long time has passed since the last time being so. The summer melancholy, the pink sunsets, the sudden night breeze that carries freshness. Watermelon. The beach. White legs on the send…

Each summer has its own soundtrack and I could say that I already have the sound of the summer of 2018. The last few months, three albums have been played the most frequently on our sound system: Wooden Shjips – V, The Babe Rainbow – Double Rainbow and Triptides – Visitors. All were released very recently, and besides having the same hook of psychedelia, they all embrace the sound of the summer.

Wooden Shjips – V (May 2018)

Is there something else to expect from a record whose front cover depicts two fingers up in the air calling for peace? V is the fifth album of the San Francisco psychedelic rockers who, even though becoming increasingly mellower with each new record, they still manage to hold their own distinctive sound. Cheerful melodies that shine with positive energy and optimism. Next September we will have the opportunity to see them live on Zdravo Mladi Festival, and this is the best news so far this year.

The Babe Rainbow – Double Rainbow (July2018)

In the same manner as on their debut album, on their sophomore effort The Babe Rainbow once again reference the sound of the late ’60s and early ’70s. Yet, this time it is done with a more laid-back groove, lacking the funky and disco elements that they had on some tracks on their previous record. Double Rainbow is a record that brings the summer breeze feel, waves, surfers and sunny beaches.

Triptides – Visitors (April 2018)

Triptides are a psychedelic rock band from Los Angeles, and Visitors is their sixth record so far. The first track “All my life” immediately sets a warm, positive and melodic beginning of the album. A similar summer ambient that evokes the era of the love revolution lurks from each corner of the album.

*

Thanks to the new psychedelic music, the summer of 2018 got its colors and sound of a summer from the late 1960s. The last couple of years I am making up for all the music that I have missed growing up in the era of grunge in which psychedelic rock was considered a kind of passe. Luckily, psychedelic rock is having a comeback riding on a new wave of the bands that make music that sounds as if it was recorded late in the 1960s, long forgotten on a shelf and rediscovered once again. It is a dose of a old-new psychedelic sound which is much needed in this digital era of crunched decibels and no sense of subtlety in music production.

I like this kind of weather since I am not a huge fan of the continental summers and extremely high temperatures (but then again, who is?). The summer…

node.title: Oceania breeze
node.content:
There is a new wave of freshness coming from the land down under. A few years back it was only a shy notion, but now it could definitely be said that Australia along with New Zealand have the most interesting and most productive alternative scenes, especially in terms of psychedelic rock.

In fact, Australia has always had a vibrant rock and roll scene. As we researched their underground scene, we realized that this continent has given us a plethora of cult bands on a global level. Still, the Australian cultural influence was not as able to penetrate the boundaries when compared to the ginormous American or British influence. Thus, in our heads, Australia remained a partial terra incongnita.

Here we list some of our favorite bands and artists originating from Australia and New Zealand.

King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard

King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard represent one of the most productive bands of the Australian scene that emerged at the start of the 2010s. Since they held their promise to release five albums in 2017 (with Gumboot soup they managed to fulfill that promise just in time on the 30th of December, 2017), the band has toured Europe and America and almost all of their dates were sold out.

The Babe Rainbow

The hippies are alive and live in Australia. It is unimaginable how The Babe Rainbow manage to sound and look as if they were literally brought to the present by a time machine. With the marry colors, sounds and positive vibrations there carry the groove and charm of the late 1960s. Their positive music shines with sunny light from the warm meadows of the south hemisphere.

Courtney Barnett

This modest Australian managed to get the world’s attention and to build a sold fan base, especially in the United States. After her collaboration with Kurt Vile, an interesting combination of two artists that resulted in their record Lotta Sea Lice, Courtney Barnett announced her second album Tell Me How You Really Feel scheduled for release in May. Three singles from the album have already been released.

Fazerdaze

Oh, those wonderful 90s! The era of flannel plaid shirts, Dr. Martens, Levis and alternative music as mainstream culture. The current generations often cite the music and fashion deriving from this era. Fazedaze is a nice girl from New Zealand whose dreampop/shoegase music is incredibly reminiscent of the 90’s and turns on the nostalgia switch right away.

Pond

Band that is inescapably related to Tame Impala. The members of both bands frequently interchange, while the former is fronted by Nick Allbrook. On their former records the music resembles psychedelic rock, but on their latest record (it could be argued in a disappointing manner) they experiment with synth pop in a similar manner as Tame Impala did on Currents. The video for the track Fire in the Water was directed by New Zealand director Sam Kristofski, who also made videos for Fazerdaze and The Babe Rainbow. The videos feature a specific vintage ascetic and a weird obsession with hands.

The Chats

Very funny and truly sipmpatico young surf-punks. Even the legendary Australian mullets found on the singer’s hairdo are completely legitimate. The simplistic punk refrain of Smoko immediately catches your ear and no wonder the song is a viral hit.

Cosmic Psychos

Old punks formed in 1977 still bringing fresh and exiting music and worthy of mention on this list. Cosmic Psychos are not only relevant in Australia, but also very influential for the Seattle scene of the 1990s. They are considered to be one of the most influential bands for the stylistic formation of grunge. Eddie Vedder himself recognized Cosmic Psychos as an early influence on him and his band.

*

More bands are worth the mention. For instance, The Murlocs, a band led by Kenny-Smith of King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, the psychedelic ORB, as well as Stonefield – four Johnny Mitchel lookalikes sisters who originate from a town called Macedon Ranges.
node.excerpt: There is a new wave of freshness coming from the land down under. A few years back it was only a shy notion, but now it could definitely be said that Australia along with New Zealand have the most interesting and most productive alternative scenes, especially in terms of psychedelic rock.
